title: 110_s3737
content: The "Sell Fuel Efficient Cars Act of 2008" includes a Passenger Automobile Trade-In Program. The "Sell Fuel Efficient Cars Act of 2008" defines terms like automobile, fuel, manufacturer, and passenger automobile. An eligible individual must have no more than 3 registered passenger automobiles, filed a federal income tax return in 2007, and not claimed a deduction under section 151 of the Internal Revenue Code. An eligible individual for the "Sell Fuel Efficient Cars Act of 2008" must have an adjusted gross income not exceeding $25,000 ($40,000 for joint filers or heads of household), not acquired an automobile under the Program, and not filed a joint return with someone who acquired an automobile under the Program. The term "eligible new automobile" for the Program refers to a passenger car that has never been registered, manufactured by a company with operations in the US crucial for the economy and jobs. The eligible new automobile for the Program must have been manufactured in the US, assembled in the US, and have a fuel economy of at least 25 miles per gallon. The eligible new automobile for the Program must have a fuel economy of at least 25 miles per gallon and meet specific criteria set by the Administrator for fuel economy testing methodologies. The term "eligible old automobile" refers to a passenger car that is operable, was first registered at least 10 years before the trade, is registered under the individual's name initiating the trade, and was registered under their name before December 1, 2008. The Fuel economy is the average miles traveled per gallon of gasoline, the Program is the Passenger Automobile Trade-In Program, and the Secretary refers to the Secretary of the Treasury. The Program provides subsidies for eligible individuals to buy new cars in exchange for old ones, starting when regulations are set and ending on December 31, 2009. The Passenger Automobile Trade-In Program, administered by the Secretary of the Treasury, provides subsidies for eligible individuals to trade in their old cars for new ones. The program started when regulations were set and will end on December 31, 2009. If an eligible individual trades in their old car for a new one, the Secretary will provide $10,000 to the seller of the new car, as long as the purchase price does not exceed the manufacturer's suggested retail price. If payment to a seller for a trade under the Program is delayed, the Secretary will provide the determined amount plus interest. An eligible individual initiates a trade by driving their old car to the seller and providing it along with any price difference for the new car. (f) Disposal of Eligible Old Automobiles: Sellers must deliver old cars for destruction as determined by the Secretary and will be compensated for incurred costs. (g) Regulations.--The Secretary will prescribe rules within 30 days of the Act's enactment to implement the Program, with expedited rulemaking procedures. Direct spending authority is granted for necessary funds, designated as an emergency requirement.
